lessons.title: The Mass-Luminosity Relationship
content: ## How Mass Determines Brightness
One of the most important discoveries in astronomy is that a star's mass determines how bright it shines. This is called the mass-luminosity relationship.
### The Power Law
For main sequence stars (normal stars like our Sun), luminosity (brightness) increases dramatically with mass:
**L ≈ M³·⁵**
This means:
- A star with 2× the Sun's mass is about 11× brighter
- A star with 10× the Sun's mass is about 3,000× brighter!
### Why Mass Matters
More massive stars have:
- Higher core pressure from gravity
- Higher core temperatures
- Faster fusion rates
- Much greater energy output
**Try it:** Compare the Sun (1 M☉) to Sirius (2.1 M☉) and Betelgeuse (20 M☉). Notice how the more massive stars glow brighter!

lessons.title: Stellar Lifecycles
content: ## From Birth to Death
Stars go through predictable lifecycles, and mass is the key factor that determines how they evolve.
### Birth: Gravitational Collapse
Stars form when clouds of gas collapse under gravity. If the collapsing cloud reaches 0.08 M☉, fusion ignites and a star is born!
### Main Sequence: Stable Fusion
Most of a star's life is spent fusing hydrogen into helium:
- Low-mass stars (< 0.5 M☉): Live for trillions of years
- Sun-like stars (0.5 - 8 M☉): Live for billions of years
- Massive stars (> 8 M☉): Live for just millions of years
### Death: How Stars End
The star's final mass determines its fate:
**Low-mass stars (< 8 M☉):**
1. Expand into red giants
2. Shed outer layers (planetary nebula)
3. Leave behind a white dwarf
**Massive stars (8 - 20 M☉):**
1. Become supergiants
2. Explode as supernovae
3. Leave behind a neutron star
**Very massive stars (> 20 M☉):**
1. Become hypergiants
2. Collapse directly into black holes
**Key insight:** More massive stars live fast and die young!

lessons.title: Nuclear Fusion and Energy
content: ## The Power Source of Stars
Stars shine because of nuclear fusion - the process of combining light atoms into heavier ones, releasing enormous energy.
### The Fusion Process
In the core of a star, hydrogen nuclei (protons) fuse together to make helium:
**4 H → He + energy**
This converts about 0.7% of the hydrogen's mass into pure energy, following Einstein's E=mc²!
### Temperature Requirements
Fusion only happens at extreme temperatures:
- **10 million K**: Minimum for hydrogen fusion
- **100 million K**: Needed for helium fusion (red giants)
- **1 billion K**: Required for heavier element fusion (supergiants)
### Why Mass Controls Fusion
More massive objects have:
- Stronger gravitational pressure
- Higher core temperatures
- Faster fusion rates
This is why:
- Brown dwarfs (< 0.08 M☉) can't sustain fusion
- Red dwarfs (0.08 - 0.45 M☉) fuse hydrogen slowly
- Massive stars (> 8 M☉) burn through fuel rapidly
**Fun fact:** The Sun converts 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium every second!

lessons.title: Neutron Stars: Extreme Density
content: ## The Densest Objects (Except Black Holes)
Neutron stars are the collapsed cores of massive stars, and they're incredibly dense!
### Formation
When a star with 8-20 M☉ explodes as a supernova, the core collapses into a neutron star with about 1.4-3 M☉.
### Incredible Density
In a neutron star:
- Protons and electrons are crushed together into neutrons
- A city-sized sphere (20 km diameter) weighs as much as the Sun
- One teaspoon of neutron star material weighs 6 billion tons!
### Extreme Properties
**Gravity:** Surface gravity is 200 billion times stronger than Earth's
**Rotation:** Can spin hundreds of times per second (pulsars)
**Magnetic field:** Trillion times stronger than Earth's
**Temperature:** Surface can reach millions of degrees
### The Chandrasekhar Limit
Neutron stars can't exceed about 3 M☉. Beyond this limit, gravity overwhelms even neutron degeneracy pressure, and the star collapses into a black hole!
**Explore:** Set the mass to 1.5 M☉ to see a typical neutron star!

lessons.title: The Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram
content: ## Classifying Stars by Mass and Temperature
The Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram is one of the most important tools in astronomy. It plots stars by their luminosity and temperature.
### The Main Sequence
Most stars (including our Sun) fall on a diagonal line called the main sequence:
- Lower left: Low-mass, cool, dim red dwarfs
- Upper right: High-mass, hot, bright blue stars
### Off the Main Sequence
Stars move off the main sequence as they age:
**Red Giants:** Low-mass stars that have exhausted core hydrogen
- Cool (red) but very bright (due to large size)
**Supergiants:** Massive stars near the end of life
- Can be red or blue, but always extremely bright
**White Dwarfs:** Dead cores of low-mass stars
- Very hot but very dim (due to small size)
### Mass Determines Position
A star's initial mass determines:
- Where it starts on the main sequence
- How long it stays there
- What path it takes when it leaves
- What kind of remnant it becomes
**Key concept:** The H-R diagram tells the life story of stars based on their mass!

lessons.title: Gravitational Effects of Mass
content: ## How Mass Warps Space and Time
Massive objects create gravity, and the more mass an object has, the stronger its gravitational pull.
### Newton's Law of Gravity
The gravitational force between two objects depends on their masses:
**F = G × (M₁ × M₂) / r²**
This means:
- Double the mass → double the force
- Ten times the mass → ten times the force
### Escape Velocity
The escape velocity is the speed needed to escape an object's gravity:
- Earth: 11 km/s
- Sun: 618 km/s
- Neutron star: ~200,000 km/s (2/3 the speed of light!)
- Black hole: > 300,000 km/s (faster than light - impossible!)
### Orbital Effects
More massive objects:
- Hold onto planets more tightly
- Can have more moons and planets
- Cause larger tides on nearby objects
### Time Dilation
Einstein discovered that massive objects slow down time! Near a black hole, time moves much slower than far away in space.
**Thought experiment:** If you watched someone fall into a black hole, you'd see them slow down and freeze at the edge - but they'd feel themselves fall in normally!
